awd_titl_txt: Clustering of Neural Activity: A Design Principle for Population Codes
awd_abstract_narration:
In virtually every part of the brain, information about the sensory environment, internal body states, or intended movements is encoded by more than one neuron. This was apparent as early as the nineteenth century from the extensive interconnectivity of nearby neurons and continues to be apparent from numerous measurements of the tuning curves and correlation of nearby neurons. Despite its fundamental importance, population neural codes are poorly understood. In this project the PI will test a recently developed principle for population code - namely, that neural activity patterns should always be organized into a discrete set of clusters. This organization is appealing, because clusters exhibit error correction, encode qualitatively different stimulus features than their constituent neurons, and can be learned in an unsupervised fashion by downstream neural circuits. Together, these properties enable a powerful form of hierarchical detection of complex stimulus features. The PI aims at developing a principle of population coding that applies widely across the brain. Furthermore, his hypothesis is connected to a model of hierarchical feature detection, which may be operating across all the ascending pathways in the neocortex. In addition, the neocortex's modular structure lends itself to machine learning algorithms. In addition,the project will involve the development and dissemination of software to perform fits of maximum entropy and hidden Markov models to neural data, which could help spur on the research programs of many labs that use these methods to analyze neural populations.

This proposal will combine large-scale neural recording methods from the retina and cortex with state-of-the-art theoretical analyses to study collective phenomena in population neural codes. The PI has an extensive track record in multi-electrode recording from the vertebrate retina, along with applying maximum entropy models to analyze states of network activity. In addition, the PI has recently started a collaboration with Prof. David Tank to record from cortical populations using two-photon calcium fluorescence imaging. The project's aims are: 1. Study how cluster codes can simultaneously encode categorical and continuous stimulus information; if true, this idea would constitute a new example of multiplexed coding in neural populations 2. Study how biologically plausible neural networks can learn and readout clusters; if true, then this makes possible hierarchical cluster processing in the neocortex and will lead us to formulate specific experimental tests to see if layer 4 of V1 is learning LGN clusters. 3. Test whether cluster codes are present in central brain areas, like the visual cortex and hippocampus; this study may generalize his results beyond the retina and help establish a new design principle for population codes. This project is being jointly supported by the Physics of Living Systems program in the Division of Physics and the Modulation Program in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems.

por.por_cntn:
Collective Phenomena in Neural Population Codes

Progress Report: March 1 2021 to February 28 2022

 

II. Products

We have two papers that have been accepted at peer-reviewed journals:

A. Schultz, C. Miehl, M.J. Berry II, and J. Gjorgjieva, "The generation of cortical novelty responses through inhibitory plasticity", eLife, 10: e65309 (2021).

J. Homann, S.A. Koay, K. Chen, D.W. Tank, and M.J. Berry II, "Novel stimuli evoke excess activity in the mouse primary visual cortex", PNAS 119(5): e2108882119 (2022).

 

And another paper published in the BioRxiv:

J. Homann, H. Kim, D.W. Tank, and M.J. Berry II, "Passive exposure sparsifies neural activity in the primary visual cortex", BioRxiv (2021); doi: https://doi.org/10.1101/2021.11.18.469160.

 

I. Accomplishments

We have primarily focused on Aim 3.

Aim 1. Explore the Analog-Digital Nature of the Population Code  

Aim 2. Develop Biologically Plausible Models of Readout Mechanisms 

Aim #2 has been accomplished in our published paper: A.R. Loback and M.J. Berry II, "A Biologically Plausible Mechanism to Learn Clusters of Neural Activity", bioRxiv (2018). doi: https://doi.org/10.1101/389155.

Aim 3. Test the Generality of Clustering as a Design Principle for Population Codes

Test models of population coding. In order to better understand how populations of neurons can constitute a cluster code, we have created an artificial neural population, loosely modeled on how LGN neurons might respond to visual stimuli. We generate patterns of population neural activity using this model and then analyze the resulting spike trains in the same manner that we analyze real, experimentally measured neural spike trains. Our generative model consists of N neurons the encode L different discrete stimuli. Each neuron has a response given the stimulus that is conditionally independent. The actual firing rate for cell i given stimulus k is rik, which is drawn from a distribution of experimentally measured firing rates (Schwartz et al., J. Neurophysiology 2012).

We analyzed the artificial spike trains using an independent hidden Markov model (HMM), as there was no temporal correlation. Then, we explored the tuning of the cluster code as we varied the number of discrete stimuli.  We found that we can achieve perfect cluster tuning when a neural population of a given size, N, encodes few enough discrete stimuli, L; then, as the number of stimuli were increased, cluster tuning began to degrade (Fig. 1). Qualitatively, this behavior is expected, and our goal is to understand the quantitative relationship between N and L. We plan to continue this investigation to map out the regime in which cluster tuning can represent discrete stimuli with high fidelity. We also plan to extend this analysis to a stimulus ensemble drawn from a continuum.

Further Developments

1. Novelty responses in the primary visual cortex. When neurons in layer 2/3 of V1 were presented with novel images, we found excess activity as well as a more dense code for sensory information. Some of these data were first published on the BioRxiv (Homann et al., 2017).  Funds from this grant were used to construct an adaptive subunit model that appears in a new published paper in this reporting period (Homann et al., PNAS 2022).

2. Generation of novelty responses by inhibitory plasticity. In collaboration with the lab of Prof. Gjorgjieva at Max Planck Frankfurt, we have formulated a model of an E/I spiking network to explain the novelty response (Schultz et al., eLife 2021). Novelty responses arise because (anti-Hebbian) synaptic plasticity in I cells increases inhibition to the repeated images, while leaving the novel images with less inhibition (Fig. 2).

III. Participants

This work has involved two graduate students, who has been funded by this grant, Pul Park and Anirudh Krishna, as well as one summer intern, Spencer Powers. This work has also involved collaboration with Julijana Gjorgjieva at the Max Planck Institute in Frankfurt, Germany.

IV. Impact

The paper published in 2021 (Schultz et al.) presents a new computational concept that can potentially explain the novelty response and stimulus-specific adaptation in general. I conceived of this project, and most of the work was carried out by my collaborator.

The paper published in 2021 (Homann et al.) presents new experimental data showing that neural populations in the visual cortex become more sparse over multiple days of passive exposure to the same visual stimuli. These data connect to a previous literature about the benefits of sparse coding. They also expand our understanding of the plasticity of the neural code, even in early visual cortex. Finally, these data demonstrate a new mechanism of unsupervised

V. Changes

None.

VI. Plans for Next Accounting Period

1) continue to explore how artificial neural populations can encode stimuli using clusters

2) continue analyzing 1000+ neuron populations recorded by the Schnitzer lab (Aim 3)

3) explore the MICrONS dataset for analyzing cortical population codes (Aim 3)
